sub_title: MSc Sustainable Development: International Development, Utrecht University
summary:
Sophie Mazur is an MSc student studying Sustainable Development (focused on international development in the global South) at Utrecht University. She holds a BA from Boston University cum laude with a major in Sociology and a dual minor in Public Health and Visual Arts. As well as an MSc from Vrije University Amsterdam in Business Administration: Leadership and Change Management. She finished with an average of 8 and wrote her thesis on 'RSV Vaccine Introduction in LMICs: Analyzing Stakeholders, Bottlenecks and Leverage Points to Create a Collaboration Approach.’ It explored how stakeholders can collaborate and utilize leverage points in order to ensure that an upcoming RSV maternal vaccine is introduced in LMICs.

She is a motivated and broadly interested young professional aspiring to pursue a career in global health, advocacy, sustainability, and research. Her experiences in helping build clean water infrastructure in Central America and spearheading a sex education program and teaching in Ghana strengthened her passion for human rights and her belief in equal opportunity for education and health. Her skills lie in her ability to work with a diverse team, to be decisive, persevere, and accept and build on constructive criticism. She hopes to approach all opportunities with integrity, enthusiasm, and an open mind.

Sophie also loves staying active and works as a ski instructor in Switzerland in the winter and plays field hockey with a competitive team for Kampong throughout the year.

MSc Sustainable Development: International Development, Utrecht University

projects.title: Serious Game: "Newtonian Shift 2.0"
projects.description:
For one of my Master courses, we were able to use a serious game “Newtonian Shift 2.0” as an intervention tool to play out potential future organizational change scenarios based on a real-life challenge faced by a Dutch energy company.
 
During this game, we were responsible for quickly responding to 4 years of transitions in the political and economic landscape. We were forced to think quickly on our feet, partake in multi-stakeholder negotiations establishing coalitions and deals across interest groups and engage our change leadership skills!

contributors.headline: MSc Sustainable Development: International Development, Utrecht University

projects.title: RSVVW 2019 Conference: A Global Conference on Novel RSV Therapeutics and Preventive Interventions
projects.description:
I have spent the last 1.5+ years planning the 5th ReSViNET Conference - "RSVVW 2019 - A Global Conference on Novel RSV Therapeutics and Preventive Interventions" held in November in Accra Ghana, Africa. I traveled to Ghana 4 times on behalf of the ReSViNET Foundation to meet with and select potential partners, make decisions regarding conference details, and ensure that everything was on course according to schedule with external partners. Additionally, I was responsible for requesting sponsorship, managing and delegating budget, all customer-service questions, all marketing design/creations, and more.

End Results:
Almost 300 attendees from 43 countries from 5 continents attended the conference. There were 58 travel grants: 34 LMIC participants and 24 Young Researchers, 100 posters and over 45 keynote speakers.

company.name: University of Puerto Rico, Río Piedras

profile_positions.company: University of Puerto Rico, Río Piedras
profile_positions.description:
For my Master's Sustainable Development thesis research, I am excited to announce that I am working as a Fellow at the University of Puerto Rico Rio Piedras: Resiliency Law Center, in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Puerto Rico faces particular and exacerbated vulnerabilities from disasters. Most recently, Hurricane Maria in 2017, the earthquake sequence in 2020 as well as the COVID-19 pandemic have posed significant long-term negative health outcomes, especially for specialized cancer care patients. The increase in exposures, vulnerabilities, and health risks, leads to increased stress on health systems worldwide but disproportionately affects countries where health inequities exist. Currently, PR is experiencing a deteriorating socioeconomic situation amidst concurrent and compounding disasters. The increasing climatic variability and socioeconomic situation make PR one of the most vulnerable countries to disasters. Thus, requires an examination of disaster management policies from a transdisciplinary and social determinants of health perspective.

Therefore, my research will be focusing on how disaster management policies can be improved to incorporate the social determinants of health for breast cancer patients. Breast cancer remains one of the highest causes of death for women in PR and its detection rate is increasing at a rate of 0.3% per year.

It is evident that without addressing the barriers imposed by social determinants of health, disaster management strategies will continue to exacerbate rather than alleviate long-term health outcomes for breast cancer patients.

I am very excited to work with the UPR RLC team on this very important research!
profile_positions.title: UPR Resiliency Law Center Fellow
Senior Associate

profile_positions.description:
At the ReSViNET Foundation, I am mainly responsible for the organization and planning of our bi-annual international conferences. 

I have spent the last 1.5 year planning the 5th ReSViNET Conference - "RSVVW 2019 - A Global Conference on Novel RSV Therapeutics and Preventive Interventions" held in November in Accra Ghana, Africa. I traveled to Ghana 4 times on behalf of the ReSViNET Foundation to meet with and select potential partners, make decisions regarding conference details, and ensure that everything was on course according to schedule with external partners. Additionally, I was responsible for requesting sponsorship, managing and delegating budget, all customer-service questions, all marketing design/creations, and more.

In October 2019, I was also responsible for the first "Kick-Off C4C(conect4children) Expert Meeting." C4C has partnered with the ReSViNET Foundation to create an expert group of physicians and researchers on Respiratory Syncytial Virus.
profile_positions.title: Junior Associate

profile_positions.description:
For the month of January, my team and I worked on a change management consulting project for Enigma Financial Consulting.

The consulting project allowed me to gain practical experiences in the field. It was an unique experience to be involved in an actual consulting project from end-to-end. I was able to improve my skills in problem analysis, presentation, building client relationships, and working within a diverse team.

It was a pleasure to work closely with the Enigma employees to tackle this assignment through conducting in-depth interviews, administering surveys and doing desk research!
profile_positions.title: Consulting Project Based Intern at Enigma Financial Consulting

profile_positions.description:
I worked as a database developer/ research assistant at University Medical Center Utrecht, my responsibilities included:

- Built database in Castor for a phase I double-blind RCT & phase II double-blind RCT 
- Created surveys, managed user rights, set up blinding via randomization key
- Built data collection tools & logic checks
- Sketched & designed logo for study
profile_positions.title: Database Developer at RSV Research Group

profile_positions.description:
At the Philips Healthcare Center of Excellence located in Andover, Massachusetts I was brought on the team to research and analyze the possible fiscal and social costs of offshoring jobs to India.

I was given the freedom to research and compile data on a range of influencing factors (fiscal, social, environmental and more) I deemed important for making an informed decision on whether or not Philips should offshore to India.

I identified, researched, and analyzed data from the United States and India comparing demographics, education, public transportation, cost of living, average income, social standing, availability of housing, cultural implications, geographic differences, hiring costs and more in order to gain a better understanding of the possible consequences (intended and unintended) from offshoring.

After the summer, I presented a 100 page cited report outlining my objectives, summary/findings, data, appendix and bibliography of all the research complimented with graphs, charts, and tables to make the data more presentable. 

Applying my sociological perspective cultivated throughout my 4 years at Boston University, I additionally included social and human factors in my research. Identifying discrepancies in living conditions, healthcare access, wages, socioeconomic status within several regions in India and more. I believed this interdisciplinary approach to the research was necessary in order to make a fiscal, moral, and sustainable choice.

This opportunity allowed me to fortify and apply many of my skills such as time management, organization, research and analysis, presentation, excel and microsoft word, and interpersonal skills with my coworkers and boss.
profile_positions.title: IT Research Intern

profile_positions.description:
As Public Relations Officer for the Global Water Brigades chapter at Boston University I was responsible for creating and promoting content about our chapter through several platforms (mainly Facebook and Instagram). I engaged viewers through creating information and interactive posts on our initiative, our members and our meetings.

Through this experience, I strengthened my understanding of how to draw in and engage more people to continue to interact and support the organization. I learned what kind of content was most effective in interesting and reaching a broader range of viewers.
profile_positions.title: Public Relations Officer

profile_positions.description:
I served as Sabor Latino's Public Relations Officer for roughly a year and half gaining insight and experience on running multiple social media platforms, time management, and improving viewer engagement.

I was responsible for updating our team's social media presence (mainly on Twitter, Instagram, Facebook and YouTube). I advertised our team's try-outs, performances, and other events to the BU community as well as the broader Boston community through this platforms. I also found new and innovative ways to shape the image of the dance team through social media through creating interactive, themed posts (i.e. "dancer of the week," "new member biography," or informative post about a certain latin style dance we perform). Additionally, I recorded and uploaded daily our practices for our members to view and use to gain insight on their dancing and what could use improvement. On our YouTube channel, I posted, titled and shared our performances.
profile_positions.title: Public Relations Officer

profile_positions.description:
After 3 years as an active member of Sabor Latino, my team voted me to be President. I was able to ease my way into my presidency by holding several other positions on the team such as Historian and Public Relations Chair.

As president of Sabor Latino, I was responsible to coordinate and reach out to old and new contacts, supporters and potential members. I coordinated with other organizations, on and off campus, organizing dance events such as dance lessons or performances. Furthermore, I was responsible for coordinating with the other executive board members by keeping an ongoing and open line of communication. I oversaw every executive board members' responsibilities and communicated with them to make sure they fulfilled their positions.

During practices, I served as a leader making sure the team stayed organized, committed, and engaged. I really enjoyed organizing with both the dance team executive board and other organizations. As well as leading, supporting, and encouraging other members to stay involved and enjoy their time as a part of the team.
profile_positions.title: President

profile_positions.description: As historian, it is my responsibility to document all events, practices and performances so that we can promote our team. In addition, I take pictures at special events and an responsible for keeping track of all our events and performances.
profile_positions.title: Historian Officer

profile_positions.description:
During my college admissions process, my favorite opportunity was to ask the tour guides about their experiences on campus. I believe this was one of the most influential factors in my decision making for where I wanted to go to college. Therefore, I decided to apply to be an admissions ambassador and tour guide for Boston University.

My Responsibilities Included:
- Leading campus tours to potential and admitted students
- Engaging prospective students and families in conversation
- Bringing students to class
- Attending staff special events
- Hosting prospective students for overnight visits

Through this experience, I've strengthened my public speaking skills. I need to be able to project loudly and clearly throughout my tours. I learned to be attentive to my audience - some tours needed an extra push in thinking about potential questions. I enjoyed interacting with a wide range of potential students and families from all over the globe with different cultural backgrounds and interests.
profile_positions.title: Admissions Ambassador/ Campus Tour Guide

volunteer_experiences.role: Teacher, Tutor, Mentor, Soccer and Field Hockey Coach
volunteer_experiences.description:
After my freshman year of college, I traveled to Accra, the capital of Ghana, to volunteer at a school for unprivileged children. I was introduced to this school through a close friend from the Dutch embassy and after hearing the story of how the school came to be I became enthusiastic to help.

I worked with the students one-on-one to help them work on specific needs in reading, writing and math. In addition I taught full classrooms of 20 students on math, writing, reading and citizenship. During my time at the school I also helped set up a 'school council'. This school council delegated a leadership role to one boy and one girl from each classroom to help the teacher maintain order. Furthermore, the school coordinator, Billa Mahmud, was in the process of starting a new program called "Rising Girls and Boys" which, was dedicated to sex and drug education. Billa recognizes the impact these factors have on students' education and hopes through education about these subjects the students will know to make the better decisions. I was responsible for spearheading this program in fruition through coordinating, organizing, and speaking at the opening.

After school I rode the school bus with the students to soccer practice. I co-coached the the soccer practices with the Ghanaian coaches working on soccer technique and scrimmaging. In addition, I was able to train with the women's national field hockey team and coach field hockey to the youth.

Through Boston University's Global Water Brigades Club I was fortunate to go on a volunteer trip to Honduras. This was my first official service trip although I have done a lot of service work in the past, and it completely changed my ideas about service work. We were about 4 hours outside of the capital of Honduras, Tegucigalpa and worked for a week with 3 close-knit communities - Huatales, Las Pilas & Tierras Coloradas - to help implement clean water infrastructure. I worked side-by-side with community members who welcomed me with open arms and made it feel like home for me over the course of the week. This project will take 6 months to be completed with a new brigade group coming in weekly to help. I spent the week digging trenches from 8 am to 5 pm. Then on one of the last days I helped lay the pipes and cover the pipes. It was great to see our work have a direct impact on the community. In addition, to helping with the implementation of clean water infrastructure we held an education for the 100 children in these 3 communities. We played songs, games, and had a lesson plan that incorporated lessons about sanitation and other important health tips. I am so excited to go on my next brigade and see the finish product of this water project in these 3 communities!

Through City Year I was given the opportunity to work with other volunteers painting and remodeling a school in Hyde Park, Boston. This school was going to be re-opened to give children in the Boston area another avenue for education. Although this project was completed over the course of a week it was a wonderful way to see direct influence of volunteer work in the Greater Boston Area.

As community service chair for Alpha Delta Pi, I organized an event for 20 women from BU's Alpha Delta Pi chapter as well as 20 women from BU's Kappa Delta chapter to volunteer for 3 hours at the Greater Boston Food Bank. We collected supplies that the Greater Boston Food Bank is in need of to donate when we went. When we were there, we organized the items into specific bins as well as sorted out the damaged, already opened or expired items. We learned about how 1 in 4 children in Massachusetts go to sleep feeling hungry and with food insecurity. Food insecurity is the idea that they don't know when their next meal will be. Through volunteering at the Greater Boston Food Bank for 3 hours we organized 5,171 meals that were sent out to families in need.

As Alpha Delta Pi's community service chair, I organized a School Supplies Drive at Boston University. For 2 weeks, women from my chapter and myself, collected school supplies (lightly used and new) from people all already campus to donate to a nearby Boston Public School - Clarence R. Edwards Middle School. We collected over 2 car loads of school supplies throughout April-August. I continued to collect school supplies in my hometown - Concord, MA - over the summer and in August coordinated with a teacher at Clarence R. Edwards Middle School to drop the materials off. The materials ranged from notebooks, binders, paper, rulers, pencils, pens, color markers and pencils to locker decorations, erasers, etc. Clarence R. Edwards Middle School is a school home to many low-income students that cannot afford new school supplies essential to their learning. We hope through reusing and donating new supplies these children can be one step closer to a bright future!

Ronald McDonald House is the national philanthropy of Alpha Delta Pi and each month several volunteers go to the house located in Brookline, MA to cook dinner for the families and staff at RMH. This was my second time volunteering at RMH and I appreciate the ability to give back to the Boston community as well as the help the RMH in any way possible. We went to the grocery store to buy the supplies needed to cook dinner - we made pasta (one batch with vegetables and one batch with chicken), we also made parsley/garlic bread, salad, and cookies!

Ronald McDonald House is the national philanthropy of Alpha Delta Pi and each month several volunteers go to the house located in Brookline, MA to cook dinner for the families and staff at RMH. This was my first time volunteering at RMH. We bought the groceries for the food we were going to make and headed over to the house. We went to the grocery store to buy the supplies needed to cook dinner - we made mac and cheese (one batch with bacon and one batch without), garlic bread, Caesar salad, and brownies! After the cleaning the kitchen, a family came into the kitchen and a boy around the age of 10 asked if he could have some of the mac and cheese. The parents later told us they had been here for several years and this was the first time that the boy was willing to try the volunteer's food - we were so touched!

During the senior spring I attended my second brigade in Nicaragua.

First we worked on a public health project in the community La Mesa del Ocote working with 2 families to bring these sanitary stations. This involved a multitude of tasks: pick-axing and shoveling to create a hole for the septic tank, mixing concrete, layering cement blocks to create the infrastructure and laying pipes. I worked with family members in Spanish to understand how the project will influence their life. José, 4 years old, worked diligently with his father and our brigade bursting with excitement to have access to these basic necessities.

After we finished, we moved to working on a water project. Similarly, we worked alongside community members digging and pick-axing trenches and laying pipes to build the infrastructure for running water. This area was 5 communities compounded into one project and is projected to serve over 1,000 people and 250 families. 

Why is this work important? Without access to in-home clean water, people - especially women and children – spend hours a day carrying heavy buckets of water for miles back their to homes often up steep inclines and in the blazing heat. Thus hindering women’s opportunity to be involved in economic activity and children’s opportunity to attend school further perpetuating the cycle of poverty. Without access to home sanitation infrastructure preventable infectious diseases continue to spread through communities.

Lastly, we traveled up the mountain to individual homes of some women to talk to them about what the project would change for them. Many of the women responded with the same story - each day they spent hours traveling more than 1 mile to get dirty water and carried 50 pounds of water at least 6 times per day back to their homes. They were filled with enthusiasm that they would be able to dedicate this time to more important tasks and not have to strain their bodies in order to gain access to a basic need.

Team Captain responsibilities: 
- Closely coordinated with the BWC team, ensured the schedule is followed, motivated the team & kept an eye on everyone’s well being
- Took inventory of all food purchases to ensure most sustainable & cost-effective
- Distributed healthy fresh breakfast daily door-to-door
- Supported activities such as Barbershop, Beauty Salon, Daycare, Sewing, Yoga Distributed donations (plates, cutlery, baby items, sunscreen, & more)
